title: What's the most detailed fictional world? - Quora

response.answer_text: It would be the Mass Effect video game world. There are many systems(solar) in the fictional galaxy (which is also named milky way) in the mass effect game series. Systems are sets of gravitationally bound non-stellar objects in orbit around one or multiple stars. It also has various star systems accessible via the Galaxy Map organized by cluster. Each system contains at least one object that the player can travel to, such as a planet, moon, space station, starship, asteroid or mass relay. They all are homes to different alien races. All races have their own characteristics and powers. There are total 15 races in their homeworlds. These worlds are the homeworlds of some of the Milky Way galaxy's known intelligent races. Human’s have their homeworld on Earth, whereas another race(alien) ‘turians.’ have their homeworld on the planet ‘Palaven’ There are total 55 worlds in the Galaxy according to the Game Wikia website page Planets. The series has 3 games in which the main character has to defend himself, his team and other systems from the antagonist races. The story includes travelling from one world to another in our spaceship through a fictional network ‘ mass relay’. There are various atmospheres, climates, situations, stories, missions in different worlds. Its an overall highly entertaining game which is set in a intricately detailed fictional universe, along with an emotional and captivating story. This game series is considered as one of the best game series ever and this fictional system which contains many worlds, may certainly be the most detailed fictional world. For more info- Why Mass Effect is the Most Important Science Fiction Universe of Our Generation Mass Effect Wiki

I would have to say it's the DiscWorld by Terry Pratchett. While there have been many worlds described in Fiction, very few have the depth of detail that the DiscWorld does, just off the top of my head I can name 10 different countries from Discworld, which all have specific cultures, climates and histories. But more than that, the detail spans the whole world, so you could actually describe the topography,(without having to look at some of the superb maps). Most fictional worlds are either mono-cultural or have interactions between a maximum of 3–4 different cultures, and they usually have specific climates and singular histories. This just isn't the case with the DiscWorld, and over the course of the many books, a very detailed and living world emerges.
